conclusion: Energy stored in an electric field is given by U = 1/2 CV^2.
C is the capacitance of the capacitor and V is the applied voltage.
Capacitance C of a cylindrical capacitor is given by C = epsilon_0 epsilon_r (pi l / ln(b/a)).
epsilon_0 is the permittivity of free space, epsilon_r is the relative permittivity, l is the length, a and b are inner and outer radii.
Since the capacitor is initially in air, epsilon_r is 1, simplifying capacitance to C = epsilon_0 (pi l / ln(b/a)).
Substitute capacitance into energy formula: U = 1/2 (epsilon_0 (pi l / ln(b/a))) V^2.
Simplify expression to U = 1/2 epsilon_0 (pi l V^2 / ln(b/a)).
Total energy stored in the capacitor before any fluid rises is U = 1/2 epsilon_0 (pi l V^2 / ln(b/a)).
Energy stored is dependent on geometry of capacitor and applied voltage V.
Presence of dielectric fluid affects capacitance and energy stored, but not initial energy calculation.
